name: forest_bird
text: In regard of impact of climate change, 49% of breeding forest species are highly vulnerable. As temperatures rise, northern hardwoods will lose their advantage. We can expect to see increasingly fewer bird species associated with northern forests.

name: snowy_plover
text: Coastal-nesting birds such as snowy plover are among the most threatened by climate change. Rising sea levels will reduce nesting areas available for coastal and salt marsh nesting birds. Birds that depend on those shellfish and fish communities for food will also be affected.

name: arctic_tern
text: The site of living for arctic tern is literally iceland, the arctic. According to rising of temperature, the arctic tern's dependence on the ice throughout their non-breeding period in Antarctica highlights the vulnerability of the species to climate change.

name: adélie_penguin
text: It is only in recent decades that we know Adélie penguins population declines are associated with warming. The researchers reported that climate change impacts on penguins in the Antarctic will likely be highly site-specific based on regional climate trends.

name: bumblebee
text: Due to the impact of climate change, the majority of bumblebee species have failed to disperse beyond their northern range limits, while suffering losses at their southern range limits. If the population of bumblebee decrease, sufficient pollination may also become hard following natural consequence.

name: butterfly
text: According to association report, around two-thirds of butterfly species have declined in the UK over the past 40 years. If this trend continues, it might have unpredictable knock-on effects for other species in the ecosystem. Only by arming ourselves with an understanding of why butterfly numbers are down can we hope to halt or reverse the decline.

name: seal
text: Marine mammal sush as seal can serve as indicators of changes in their ocean environment. Despite being resilient animals, rising ocean temperatures, ocean acidification, and rising sea levels are just some aspects of climate change that will impact marine mammals, their food sources, and their homes.

name: tiger
text: Tigers are among the world’s most threatened species regarding climate change impact. Furthermore, one of the world’s largest tiger populations could disappear by the end of this century as rising sea levels caused by climate change destroy their habitat.

name: monkey
text: Fresh fruit and leaf eaters such as Apes are live in  high-altitude habitats. But if climate temperature goes up, they're sitting on top of mountains with nowhere else to go.

name: gorilla
text: Fresh fruit and leaf eaters such as Apes are live in high-altitude habitats. But if climate temperture goes up, they're sitting on top of mountains with nowhere else to go.

name: sea_lion
text: Marine mammal such as sea lion can serve as indicators of changes in their ocean environment. Despite being resilient animals, rising ocean temperatures, ocean acidification, and rising sea levels are just some aspects of climate change that will impact marine mammals, their food sources, and their homes.

name: polar_bear
text: Polar bears are the poster child for the impacts of climate change on species. Since their importantly site of living is sea ice. It is important to increase monitoring of polar bear populations, particularly their responses to declining sea ice.

name: cod
text: The size of marine populations has declined by almost between 1970 and 2012 according to WWF’s Living Blue Planet Report 2015. Seafood is our last major food source that is truly wild.The stakes are high when we consider how intrinsically linked the health of our oceans is to our environmental, social and economic wellbeing.

name: shark
text: The increase in temperature over the last few years has negatively affected the habitat of sharks and endangers their lives. In conclusion, global warming has made it difficult for sharks to continue surviving since the sea level and temperature of the water are tend to keep rising.

name: blue_whiting
text: The size of marine populations has declined by almost between 1970 and 2012 according to WWF’s Living Blue Planet Report 2015. Seafood is our last major food source that is truly wild.The stakes are high when we consider how intrinsically linked the health of our oceans is to our environmental, social and economic wellbeing.

name: frog
text: Changing weather patterns from global climate change could be a contributing factor in declining amphibian populations, particularly for species that rely on ephemeral water sources.

name: snake
text: Many reptiles are highly sensitive to the altered temperatures that may result from climate change due to their ectothermy which requires that they rely on ambient environmental temperatures to maintain critical physiological processes.

name: lizard
